Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the era of Newton, mathematics has been a key tool in helping us comprehend the nature of the universe. Famous examples are calculus via Newtonian mechanics and differential geometry via Einstein's theory of general relativity. During the last twenty years, there has been a great deal of activity devoted to building a so-called string-theoretic model of the universe, which incorporates some of the most sophisticated mathematics. The subject of Gromov-Witten theory was born twenty years ago during a period of intensive interaction between mathematics and physics. Since then Gromov-Witten theory has established itself as a central area in both geometry and physics. At the same time, it has expanded greatly in its scope to many diverse areas of mathematics, ranging from the classical topic of Hurwitz theory to the modern area of Donaldson-Thomas invariants (the sheaf-theoretic counterpart of Gromov-Witten theory). Despite its success, many central problems remain unsolved. Two notable examples are the computation of higer genus Gromov-Witten invariants of compact Calabi-Yau manifolds and the precise relation between Gromov-Witten and Donaldson-Thomas invariants. The resolution of these problems is of great importance for geometry and physics. In this proposal, a team of the best experts in the world is assembled to attack these central problems. In addition, the PIs propose to develop technology to study a variety of questions relating Gromov-Witten theory to enumerative algebraic geometry, symplectic geometry and mathematical physics. The PIs hope to make important and substantial contributions to these areas of mathematics, and their interrelations.

This project is interdisciplinary in nature, in that both physical and mathematical ideas play central roles. In this sense it adds to the current trend of interaction between mathematics and physics. This project emphasizes teamwork and collaboration. Through research seminars, organizing and participating in national and international conferences, this proposal will also enhance the training of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows. There will be a number of research publications that will help in introducing students to this exciting area of mathematics.

This award is cofunded by the Algebra and Number theory and the Topology programs of DMS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
String theory, a branch of theoretical physics, has been producing interesting mathematical implications, in addition to explanation of natural phenomena. One of the most famous examples is  the astonishing prediction of the number of rational curves in a quintic threefold using a duality  known as mirror symmetry. Gromov-Witten (GW) theory and quantum cohomology have been developed to give rigorous mathematical formulation and proof of the prediction of mirror symmetry. GW invariants count parametrized algebraic curves in projective/quasi-projective manifolds, or more generally, parametrized holomorphic curves in Kähler manifolds. GW invariants of threefolds are related to Gopakumar-Vafa (GV) invariants which count embedded curves  and Donaldson-Thomas (DT) invariants which count ideal sheaves of curves. Quantum cohomology and quantum K-theory of Nakajima quiver varieties (which play a key role in supersymmetric gauge theories) can be best understood via representation theory.

The project has produced the following significant results regarding Nakajima quiver varieties, GW/GV/DT theory, mirror symmetry, and beyond: description of quantum cohomology of Nakajima quiver varieties via representation theory of quantum groups; construction of an analogue of the quantum dynamical Weyl group acting on the equivariant K-theory of an arbitrary Nakajima quiver variety; construction of stable envelopes in equivariant elliptic cohomology of Nakajima quiver varieties, and application to the computation of the monodromy of q-difference equations arising in the enumerative K-theory of rational curves in Nakajima quiver varieties; formulation of a two-parameter generalization of the geometric Langlands correspondence and proof of the correspondence for all simply-laced Lie algebras; mathematical formulations of 5-dimensional M-theoretic invariants; proof of the Oblomkov-Shende Conjecture relating geometry of Hilbert scheme and the HOMFLY polynomial of algebraic links; properties of cohomological Donaldson-Thomas invariants and potential applications to cluster algebras; an ansatz to define Gopakumar-Vafa invariants of Calabi-Yau threefolds using perverse sheaves of vanishing cycles; proof of the Bouchard-Klemm-Mariño-Pasquetti Remodeling Conjecture, which can be viewed as  all genus open-closed mirror symmetry for symplectic toric Calabi-Yau 3-orbifolds; proof of a generalized version of the Norbury-Scott Conjecture, which can be viewed as all genus equivariant mirror symmetry for the projective line.

The project has trained a group of graduate students, including five recent PhDs and more than ten PhDs in progress; all of the five recent PhDs are continuing their research on topics related to the project, as tenure-track assistant professors or postdocs in top mathematics departments. The training activities include topic courses taught by the investigators and weekly seminars organized by the investigators. The award has provided funding for a workshop on Gromov-Witten theory in Spring 2013, weekly seminars, participation of conferences, and visits for collaboration.
